data.text:
@aschiff @Thoughtfulnz pffff, I guess if you think an overfitted model "looks better"! 

Seriously, I universally prefer GAMs to loess. Former has smooth derivatives (help for WTP applications) and resist the tendency to over-fit local neighbourhood. And you can implement them in brms using s(x).
@bjjanssen Where's that better wastewater testing we were promised

@StuartBDonovan @Thoughtfulnz "Somewhat anecdotally, loess gives a better appearance"

You probably should have a word with whoever writes the ggplot manual

@aschiff The problem is the case numbers are no longer reliable

Garbage in ...

@Thoughtfulnz @aschiff the default parameter for LOESS is in the bin!

Sorry, just a GAM fan.

@aschiff @tslumley And that is the big issue about "peaks" is that they are made up of myriad local aggregates. 
There's a decreasing chance of getting infected in the hypothetical supermarket (but likely increasing chances at local maxima as it moves more slowly through uninfected demographics)

@Thoughtfulnz @tslumley I think you're probably right. Unfortunately, the worst day for Auckland is not the same thing as the worst day for me personally, since I don't seem to have been infected yet ...

@aschiff @tslumley I mean, I was picking a national peak as going to have occurred in what was the past week, so understandably I reckon Auckland (for current variants circulating and given levels of stringency around mask wearing and keeping it out of rest homes etc) has had its single worst day
